newsitem.title: USA: DoubleClick unveils Internet ad tracking product.
newsitem.headline: DoubleClick unveils Internet ad tracking product.

text.p: DoubleClick Inc, an Internet advertising network, on Wednesday said it was introducing proprietary software and a service to allow customers to track the performance of advertisements on the World Wide Web.

Jeff Dickey, vice president of business development at the New York-based company, said a new technology called Spotlight enables customers to monitor the number of pages "clicked through" by an individual user and to determine the point at which the user seeks more information or makes a purchase.

Dickey and David Henderson, vice president of North American sales, said the technology would improve the ability of advertisers to target individual consumer tastes and produce qualified leads and purchases.

"Our business is not just eyeballs," or the number of people who use their mouse to click on banner advertisements to view -- or eyeball -- an advertiser's site on the Internet's World Wide Web, Dickey said.
The two executives said the technology matches a shift in advertising on the Web from general branding to more specific targeting to produce responses.

While the survey found that most Internet advertisers are still high-tech companies advertising on one another's sites, DoubleClick has detected a big increase in Web advertising plans by the consumer product companies -- among the biggest advertisers in national magazines and on television and radio.
"The reality is that the Internet is the greatest empowerment tool in history," Dickey said of the allure of using the medium for advertising to individuals.

DoubleClick Network was launched less than six months ago. The company was formed in March after the merger of a division of Bozell Worldwide's Poppe Tyson advertising agency with the Atlanta-based Internet Advertising Network.
Last month, the company surpassed the 10 million-user mark, the company said.
